comments.author: lopakasail

comments.text:
+миро родозов Actually, I was vegan for seven years. It felt great at 
first, but over time I began to develop increasing health problems, 
including agonizing abdominal pain of a mysterious origin, constant fatigue 
and depression, panic attacks, intense sugar cravings, even fainting 
spells. I was eating lots of veggies, fruit, tempeh, olive oil, beans, 
brown rice, nuts, etc. While I admit that I could have done better about 
vitamin supplementation (of course might we not ask why this would be 
necessary for a diet suggested as the ideal?) and that some people may do 
better on it than others, I can say from personal experience that I feel 
much healthier consuming a higher-fat omnivorous diet. Humans evolved 
eating meat. There are no traditional vegetarian (let alone vegan) 
societies for a reason. I would rather take my chances with the diet that 
humans have been following for 99% of their existence than trust some 
cooked studies funded by agribusiness.
+ShadowSarah It's not just modern agriculture that destroys topsoil, but 
agriculture itself. When you deforest and then till the soil, there will be 
erosion. Traditionally, agricultural societies begin in the floodplains, 
with their nutrient-rich alluvium deposits. As populations expanded, they 
gradually moved up the slopes of the valleys, worsening erosion and leading 
to desertification. This is why the soil of the historic centers of 
civilization (Italy, Greece, Northern Africa, the Middle East, etc.) is 
mostly sand and rocks. The Epic of Gilgamesh, perhaps the oldest written 
story, depicts Gilgamesh cutting down the great Cedar forests of Sumer in 
defiance of the gods.

And fiber slows digestion because it makes things *harder* to digest, and 
in the case of insoluble fiber cannot be digested or absorbed at all. 
Excessive insoluble fiber can bind to minerals, preventing their 
absorption, and inhibit pancreatic enzyme production. If people ever have 
undigested food in their stool, it's most likely going to be a high-fiber 
plant food.
comments.author: starfish prime

comments.text:
+starfish prime Are you serious? Sure, modern agriculture destroys topsoil, 
but that's our own fault, as is the way we handle the meat industry. And 
animal products contain absolutely no fiber, so what makes you think 
they're more digestible than plants?
comments.author: Musical Pears

comments.text: THANK YOU.

comments.text:
Humans are omnivores, not vegetarians. And the animals that live on insects

comments.author: Tim Hansen

comments.text:
+deafheart23 I'm sorry, but I actually think it is *you* who are 
ill-informed. There is a big difference between "feeding" people and 
nourishing them. Plant-based foods cannot even approach animal products in 
terms of fat-soluble vitamins, protein, or digestibility. You decry wasting 
land on animal feed, while ignoring the fact that these ruminant animals 
are not even being fed their natural diets of grass. Animals raised on 
pasture can actually build topsoil and increase biodiversity, unlike 
agriculture, which has the opposite effect. I must also disagree with you 
concerning atherosclerosis. The notion that cholesterol or saturated fat 
cause heart disease is a myth.
comments.author: starfish prime

comments.text:
+deafheart23
Cricket flour would be cheaper and pack more nutrients than just vegetarian 
food. While these charities you mentioned may use vegetarian meals to feed 
people, that doesn't negate the fact that people are naturally omnivores. 
You need to supplement a vegetarian diet in order to get the full nutrients 
you need. Sure, if someone is *literally starving*, they will be healthier 
if someone came in and fed them a vegetarian diet. I am saying they would 
be even healthier if you added meat to that. The protein alone would be a 
drastic improvement for  their immune system and muscle building.
comments.author: CERULEANSPIRAL

comments.text:
+CERULEANSPIRAL  Apologies, but you have absolutely no idea what you're 
talking about. The worlds largest feed the hungry group is Food for Life 
Global ( http://www.ffl.org/en/ ), they feed people 2 million meals a day 
using solely vegetarian and vegan food. The worlds second largest group 
PLENTY ( http://www.plentyfood.org/ ) does the same thing. These two 
organizations both feed starving people using plant based foods because 
it's CHEAPER that way, plus they feed 20 to 30 times more people than the 
groups that use meat.
 
If we can ever hope to cure world hunger we need to abandon the current 
mainstream agricultural practices where 95% of soy, 77% of oats, and 80% of 
corn farmed in America is animal feed! One acre of land can yield 50,000 
pounds of tomatoes, 30,000 pounds of carrots, 40,000 pounds of potatoes, 
but that same acre of land can only give you 250 pounds of meat. We would 
destroy less land and less habitat if we ate our crops directly. 

As far as man being omnivores, I would advise you to educate yourself. Real 
meat eaters have a nutritional need to eat meat, if they don't eat meat 
they die. No human is ever going to die from not eating meat and as far as 
protein goes broccoli has more protein than a slice of steak anyway. It's 
also impossible for any true meat eater to ever clog their arteries, their 
physiology doesn't allow it. No wolf, lion, or bear is ever going to need 
bypass surgery from their heavy meat eating. But what do heavy-meat eating 
humans get? ATHEROSCLEROSIS. As they say, knowledge is power, spread that, 
not ignorance. Jenna Marbles fans attack! Are we omnivores?
comments.author: deafheart23

comments.text:
+Troy Eilertson
Actually we need more protein. If we ate more protein and fresh fruit/veg 
and less flour/breads/starches we would be healthier and less likely to be 
overweight/obese and/or unhealthy. Replacing wheat flour with cricket flour 
would go a long way toward that. Vegetarianism isn't doing that.

On top of that, working on curing world hunger- people are omnivores. They 
just are. You can choose not to eat meat or animal products and supplement 
supplement supplement- but the fastest, cheapest, easiest way to feed 
people includes animal products- specifically insects. Which are plentiful, 
easy to care for, and cheap.
comments.author: CERULEANSPIRAL

comments.text:
You don't understand what I was saying. My point is that people don't NEED 
as much protein as we eat now, we don't need cricket flour to replace plant 
flours. Her argument rests on people wanting a fixed amount of protein and 
that we need to replace meat with insect flour to sustain that level of 
protein consumption. My argument is just that we don't need that much 
protein, and that replacing it is pointless when we can just have less of 
it in our diet. People will eat plant based flours and eat less meat as it 
becomes prohibitively expensive and have a lower protein diet LONG before 
they eat cricket flours. No one will die or have their lifespans cut short 
from it.
comments.author: Troy Eilertson

comments.text:
+Troy Eilertson is the point to help people in the fastest, cost-effective 
and most practical way, or to make them vegan/vegetarian?

Like it or not, these two are not congruent. Veganism and vegetarianism are 
not compatible with cheap lifestyles. Cricket flour is a cheap protein 
replacement. Veg protein sources are far more expensive per pound.

You're speaking as if the point is to get people to eat less meat. But this 
is not a drive for veganism. This is a drive for helping poor people. 
Crickets are cheaper than traditional meat protein sources. Vegetarian 
protein sources are... ding ding... NOT. How off base could you get?
comments.author: anovermage

comments.text:
+Robert Nathan Allen But people don't need to replace FLOUR and people get 
enough protein without crickets. We don't need cricket flour, we need a 
meat replacement or to eat less meat, which can be done without the cricket 
flour. This cricket flour won't get people to eat less meat any more than 
plain wheat flour will. Her argument is a little pointless in this regard. 

People can get enough protein being vegetarian and vegan so what is the 
point of cricket flour? It's not a meat replacement so how is it supposed 
to get people to eat less meat or stop eating it entirely?
comments.author: Troy Eilertson

comments.text:
Cricket cookies are just the first step. The goal is to SUPPLEMENT, not 
replace, traditional foods like burgers and hotdogs (c'mon, you'll eat 
what's in a hotdog and turn your nose up at a clean healthy cricket?). 
Also, nobody is advocating putting live bugs in your food. Insects are 
unique as a food source because unlike other animals, they can be raised 
humanely and culled ethically.

Insects raised for food will be grown in inclosed environments, so we're 
not starving the animals that traditionally eat insects.

I think Megan would agree that there are 1899 other species we know are 
edible, so we can decide not to eat bees until CCD isn't a threat to the 
population.

I agree that a vegan lifestyle would be ideal for a large part of the 
population, but the truth is, that reality is a little further off. We have 
people starving all over the world and even here in America, today; 
something needs to change now. Edible insects is way to fight malnutrition 
not just abroad, but here in America where large parts of the population 
are struggling with protein, iron, and calcium deficiencies. It's also an 
incredible way to mitigate so many of the environmental woes that are the 
result of the agricultural industry. That being said, I find it hard to 
believe anybody would advocate against taking this important first step in 
making the world a better place.

We're eating bugs for a better tomorrow.
comments.author: Robert Nathan Allen

top_comment.text:
The problem is not a lack of food.  The problem is a lack of poor people's 
ability to buy it and the super rich, especially in countries like Saudi 
Arabia, leaching off the world economic system (especially the oil system), 
wasting ungodly amounts of money and resources on themselves and their 
spoiled, fat-assed vacationing citizens.  The Open Fuel Standard Act, and 
especially methanol, would stop that, empower the poor, de-finance radical 
Islam, and give us a proper baseline for the future.  Fringe, 
hard-to-implement and distasteful ideas like cricket cookies, rationing, or 
population control shouldn't even be entering the discussion right now.  
Not surprisingly, you will not hear this in any establishment-vetted TED 
discussions.﻿
top_comment.author: Reticuli

comments.text: +Reticuli Ok.  Thanks for the replies.
comments.author: Vane Fal

comments.text:
Blaming individual buying decisions makes about as much sense as people not 
eating red meat and only riding a bicycle in Portland thinking they're 
going to single-handedly prevent global climate change.  This is not 
self-righteousness but about practical solutions that can be implemented in 
society by properly using government.  Airbags. Catalectic converters.  
IEEE standards. Railroad gauge.  I'm not talking about banning the use of 
oil, but forcing oil to compete with alcohols in the world economy by 
breaking these cartels and disrupting the conflicts-of-interests, reaching 
critical mass through the use of demand-side mandates versus supply-side 
subsidies or limiting choice options.  And by the way, everything that is 
made out of oil can now be made out of alcohols.  A guy won a Nobel Prize 
for figuring out the chemical path for it.  Will oil still be used a 
hundred years from now?  Sure.  But it does not need to be the dominant 
vehicle fuel, nor do we need to be beholden to corrupt foreign regimes.
comments.author: Reticuli

comments.text:
+Reticuli Do you use products made of oil?  If so, its hypocritical of you 
to lay blame upon the suppliers - no matter how much detail about their 
actions you wish to ascribe to them - because you yourself are supporting 
them with your purchases.  So as a buyer, you are the problem.  What are 
you going to do about it?
comments.author: Vane Fal

comments.text:
The problem is the majority of car companies are actually partially owned 
by Kuwait, the Saudis, the Emirates, and a bunch of Wall Street investors 
with big stakes in oil.  Our cars don't even have to run on gas anymore.  
Most new engines are capable of being run off any alcohol, including 
methanol, in any concentration.  I'm not just talking E10, here.  Guess why 
your fuel injection system's firmware and fuel seals in your car are 
intentionally not compatible with this?

comments.text: The problem is people like to buy oil.  Do you buy it or not?

comments.text:
colony collapse is certainly a concern, but there are things you might be 
unaware of. Colony collapse does not affect all bees and there are plenty 
of species that are healthy as ever. In fact, the concern about colony 
collapse is not that it is destroying all the bees, but that we don't 
understand it so we are worried if it could. Also, the number of bees that 
people produce in agriculture is still massive. In interesting parallel was 
when I visited a turtle farm. The farm was build to introduce endangered 
sea turtles back into the wild. However, they produced more turtles than 
would be safe to reintroduce (due to overcrowding, disease, competition, 
etc). So although in the wild the turtles were endangered, on the farm they 
had a glut. Because of this, they turned some of the excess turtles into 
food. Its the only place you can legally eat the turtles.

captions.text: When you hear crickets chirping, what do you think of? Warm summer nights, grassy fields, the awkward silence that happens when a joke falls flat?
When I think of crickets, I think of the future of food. Because I eat crickets almost everyday in the form of baked goods, like this, which I made from cricket flour.
It might be difficult for a lot of people to consider eating whole insects, but they become a lot more manageable when they're in this format.
This is cricket flour, which I make from whole insects that are dried and milled into a fine, nutty powder.
And it's packed with nutrients, it has healthy fats, vitamins and minerals, and around 70 grams of protein per serving.

And I'm in pretty good company when it comes to eating insects.This dish that you see right here is served at Noma in Copenhagen, which has been named the number one restaurant in the world for the past several years.
We can even say that crickets are on the cusp of becoming trendy.
In my previous life before I started Bitty Foods, I was a trend forecaster and consumer researcher in the media and technology industries.
And looking through the lens of a trend forecaster, I see a powerful shift happening in the way that people think about food
People are more interested in sustainability than ever before and understanding where their food comes from, which is why we're all here today.
And thanks to the internet, we're constantly being exposed to new trends and ideas and even new cuisines.
Like this three bee salad from Chef David George Gordon. You may already know some of the reasons why eating insects is a good idea.
By the year 2050, there will be an additional 2 billion people on the planet and economists say that we are unlikely to have the food resources to feed everyone.
We are facing a global food crisis. And our current agricultural production will not scale to feed 9+ billion people.
Economists say that by the year 2050, meat will become a luxury product. In their direst estimates, beef will be priced like caviar.
It will be a rare luxury for many of us, and for many many more of us, it will be completely unattainable.

Insects, on the other hand, are a highly sustainable form of protein. They can be grown with very little land and very little water, and they have a feed to meat conversion ratio 10 times more efficient than beef.
Insects are in fact, the most efficient form of protein on planet Earth. Last May, the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization published a 200 page report
that made world headlines for its conclusion that edible insects could be the key to global food sustainability.

Among their findings, if everyone in the world started eating insects, and they became a part of our mainstream food supply, we could reclaim 30% of the earth's land surface, which is currently being used by the livestock industry
to grow animals and the grains that the animals eat. That's a third of the Earth.
We could reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by 18% and we could lower the cost of food all around the world by about 33%.
I can't think of another food source that could have this kind of impact on both the environment and the global economy, and that in a nutshell is why I eat bugs.
But eating bugs doesn't normally look like this. This is me in my kitchen baking cricket flour muffins. Normally when we think about eating insects, we think of people in times of strife
desperate people who are in a famine situation or Fear Factor contestants. But I'm looking to change that perception by turning insects into an aspirational food.
A highly nutritious food that is sought out by thought leaders like you, and I think we can do that in the next couple of years.
And I also think that within the next decade, insects will move from being a crazy, edgy food to being a completely mainstream food for most people.

To help foster that cultural change, I'm starting with the cricket. There are 2,000 different species of insects that can be eaten and are eaten by humans around the world, but I think crickets have a very nice cultural association for Westerners.

Like we talked about before with the nice chirping and the summer nights. And, they don't carry any diseases that are transmissible to humans, and not to be confused with locusts, they don't destroy crops either.

Although crickets are delicious boiled, sautéed, fried, and in many other preparations, I think that reducing their friction and making them more easy to think about, by turning them into a flour is the way that we're going to be able to introduce them to the Western world.
And so, I turn them into a nutty tasting earthy flour and I bake them into cookies and muffins, and other baked goods through my company Bitty Foods.
And if you are convinced as I am, that insects are worth trying, I invite you to join me in tasting some cricket cookies when we break for lunch. Thank you.

title: Are insects the future of food?: Megan Miller at TEDxManhattan
